note: Her own publications are mainly on Middle English romance and on the theory and practice of editing medieval popular texts. Her most recent publication is an edition of Richard Johnson’s prose romance The Seven Champions of Christendom (1596/97).
title: In 1980 she was awarded a Ph.D. by the University of Cambridge for a study and edition of the Middle English romance of Sir Bevis of Hampton. Since then she has worked in academic publishing: she was Assistant Editor of Medium Ævum (1978–97) and now edits the Modern Humanities Research Association’s Annual Bibliography of English Language and Literature

container-title: His awards include several Fulbright Fellowships (1960–61, 1984), a Guggenheim Fellowship (1978–79
note: and an appointment at the Netherlandish Institute at Wassenaar (1995–96). He now lives in Vermont, where he recently completed Pieter Bruegel and the Art of Laughter.
title: He received his doctorate from Harvard University in 1969 and taught at Case Western University (Cleveland, Ohio), from which he retired in
He has published books on Bosch, Bruegel, and landscape painting, most recently Pleasant Places: The Rustic Landscape from Bruegel to Ruisdael

author.literal: Terry Pearson received her M.A. in English from London University in

note: Since retiring, she has developed interests in the art and imagery of the medieval English church, focusing particularly on the history of the mermaid.
title: She taught English in further and higher education before she returned to her native Devon, where she taught interdisciplinary courses on the Renaissance and Reformation for the Open University until 1999

note: Her most recent monograph, co-authored by Achim Landwehr, is an introduction into European Cultural History: Einführung in die Europäische Kulturgeschichte, (Paderborn 2004).
title: Stefanie Stockhorst received her Ph.D. from the University of Göttingen with a thesis on Goethe’s poetry for occasions. In 2000, she took up her present post as a Lecturer at the Department of European Cultural History at the University of Augsburg. She was a Visiting Scholar at London, Cambridge, and Yale. In 2004, she was elected to be a member of the Executive Board of the German Society for Eighteenth Century Studies. Her major research interest is German literature from 1700–2000 with particular reference to the relationship between literature and medicine
